items.title: The overlooked driver of digital transformation
items.summary: When business leaders talk about digital transformation, their focus often jumps straight to cloud platforms, AI tools, or collaboration software. Yet, one of the most fundamental enablers of how organizations now work, and how employees experience that work, is often overlooked: audio. As Genevievโฆ
items.body: When business leaders talk about digital transformation, their focus often jumps straight to cloud platforms, AI tools, or collaboration software. Yet, one of the most fundamental enablers of how organizations now work, and how employees experience that work, is often overlooked: audio. As Genevieve Juillard, CEO of IDC, notes, the shift to hybrid collaboration made every space, from corporate boardrooms to kitchen tables, meeting-ready almost overnight. In the scramble, audio quality often lagged, creating what research now shows is more than a nuisance. Poor sound can alter how speakers are perceived, making them seem less credible or even less trustworthy. “Audio is the gatekeeper of meaning,โ stresses Julliard. โIf people can’t hear clearly, they can’t understand you. And if they can’t understand you, they can’t trust you, and they can’t act on what you said. And no amount of sharp video can fix that.” Without clarity, comprehension and confidence collapse. For Shure, which has spent a century advancing sound technology, the implications extend far beyond convenience. Chris Schyvinck, Shureโs president and CEO, explains that ineffectivโฆ

items.summary: This is todayโs edition of The Download, our weekday newsletter that provides a daily dose of whatโs going on in the world of technology. Welcome to Kenyaโs Great Carbon Valley: a bold new gamble to fight climate change In June last year, startup Octavia Carbon began running a high-stakes test in tโฆ
items.body: This is today’s edition of The Download , our weekday newsletter that provides a daily dose of what’s going on in the world of technology. Welcome to Kenyaโs Great Carbon Valley: a bold new gamble to fight climate change In June last year, startup Octavia Carbon began running a high-stakes test in the small town of Gilgil in south-central Kenya. Itโs harnessing some of the excess energy generated by vast clouds of steam under the Earthโs surface to power prototypes of a machine that promises to remove carbon dioxide from the air in a manner that the company says is efficient, affordable, andโcruciallyโscalable. The companyโs long-term vision is undoubtedly ambitiousโit wants to prove that direct air capture (DAC), as the process is known, can be a powerful tool to help the world keep temperatures from rising to ever more dangerous levels.  But DAC is also a controversial technology, unproven at scale and wildly expensive to operate. On top of that, Kenyaโs Maasai people have plenty of reasons to distrust energy companies. Read the full story . โ Diana Kruzman This article is also part of the Big Story series: MIT Technology Review โs most important, ambitious repoโฆ

items.title: Whatโs next for AI in 2026

In an industry in constant flux, sticking your neck out to predict whatโs coming next may seem reckless. (AI bubble? What AI bubblโฆ
items.body: MIT Technology Review โs Whatโs Next series looks across industries, trends, and technologies to give you a first look at the future. You can read the rest of them here . In an industry in constant flux, sticking your neck out to predict whatโs coming next may seem reckless. (AI bubble? What AI bubble?) But for the last few years weโve done just thatโand weโre doing it again.  How did we do last time? We picked five hot AI trends to look out for in 2025 , including what we called generative virtual playgrounds , a.k.a world models (check: From Google DeepMindโs Genie 3 to World Labsโs Marble , tech that can generate realistic virtual environments on the fly keeps getting better and better); so-called reasoning models (check: Need we say more? Reasoning models have fast become the new paradigm for best-in-class problem solving); a boom in AI for science (check: OpenAI is now following Google DeepMind by setting up a dedicated team to focus on just that); AI companies that are cozier with national security (check: OpenAI reversed position on the use of its technology for warfare to sign a deal with the defense-tech startup Anduril to help it take down battlefield drones ); and โฆ

items.body: The most amazing drummer on the internet My daughter introduced me to El Estepario Siberianoโs YouTube channel a few months back, and I have been obsessed ever since. The Spanish drummer (real name: Jorge Garrido) posts videos of himself playing supercharged cover versions of popular tracks, hitting his drums with such jaw-dropping speed and technique that he makes other pro drummers shake their heads in disbelief. The dozens of reaction videos posted by other musicians are a joy in themselves.  EL ESTEPARIO SIBERIANO VIA YOUTUBE Garrido is up-front about the countless hours that it took to get this good. He says he sat behind his kit almost all day, every day for years. At a time when machines appear to do it all, thereโs a kind of defiance in that level of human effort. Itโs why my favorites are Garridoโs covers of electronic music, where he out-drums the drum machine. Check out his version of Skrillex and Missy Elliotโs โRa Ta Ta โ and tell me it doesnโt put happiness in your heart. items.body: The Italian neurosurgeon Sergio Canavero has been preparing for a surgery that might never happen. His idea? Swap a sick personโs headโor perhaps just the brainโonto a younger, healthier body. Canavero caused a stir in 2017 when he announced that a team he advised in China had exchanged heads between two corpses. But he never convinced skeptics that his technique could succeedโor to believe his claim that a procedure on a live person was imminent. The Chicago Tribune labeled him the โP.T. Barnum of transplantation.โ Canavero withdrew from the spotlight. But the idea of head transplants isnโt going away. Instead, he says, the concept has recently been getting a fresh look from life-extension enthusiasts and stealth Silicon Valley startups. Career path Itโs been rocky. After he began publishing his surgical ideas a decade ago, Canavero says, he got his โpink slipโ from the Molinette Hospital in Turin, where heโd spent 22 years on staff. โIโm an out-of-the-establishment guy. So that has made things harder, I have to say,โ he says. items.title: Why inventing new emotions feels so good
items.summary: Have you ever felt โvelvetmistโ? Itโs a โcomplex and subtle emotion that elicits feelings of comfort, serenity, and a gentle sense of floating.โ Itโs peaceful, but more ephemeral and intangible than contentment. It might be evoked by the sight of a sunset or a moody, low-key album. If you havenโt eโฆ
items.body: Have you ever felt โvelvetmistโ?  Itโs a โcomplex and subtle emotion that elicits feelings of comfort, serenity, and a gentle sense of floating.โ Itโs peaceful, but more ephemeral and intangible than contentment. It might be evoked by the sight of a sunset or a moody, low-key album.   If you havenโt ever felt this sensationโor even heard of itโthatโs not surprising. A Reddit user named noahjeadie generated it with ChatGPT, along with advice on how to evoke the feeling. With the right essential oils and soundtrack, apparently, you too can feel like โa soft fuzzy draping ghost floating through a lavender suburb.โ Donโt scoff: Researchers say more and more terms for these โneo-ยญemotionsโ are showing up online, describing new dimensions and aspects of feeling. Velvetmist was a key example in a journal article about the phenomenon published in July 2025. But most neo-emotions arenโt the inventions of emo artificial intelligences. Humans come up with them, and theyโre part of a big change in the way researchers are thinking about feelings, one that emphasizes how people continuously spin out new ones in response to a changing world.  Velvetmist mightโve been a chatbot oneโฆ

We hosted 14 exclusive virtual conversations with our editors and outside experts in our subscriber-only series, Roundtables, and hโฆ
items.body: It’s been a busy and productive year here at MIT Technology Review . We published magazine issues on power , creativity , innovation , bodies , relationships , and security . We hosted 14 exclusive virtual conversations with our editors and outside experts in our subscriber-only series, Roundtables , and held two events on MITโs campus. And we published hundreds of articles online, following new developments in computing, climate tech, robotics, and more. As the year winds down, we wanted to give you a chance to revisit a bit of this work with us. Whether we were covering the red-hot rise of artificial intelligence or the future of biotech, these are some of the stories that resonated the most with our readers.  We did the math on AIโs energy footprint. Hereโs the story you havenโt heard. Understanding AIโs energy use was a huge global conversation in 2025 as hundreds of millions of people began using generative AI tools on a regular basis. Senior reporters James OโDonnell and Casey Crownhart dug into the numbers and published an unprecedented look at AIโs resource demand, down to the level of a single query, to help us know how much energy and water AI may require moviโฆ

items.title: The paints, coatings, and chemicals making the world a cooler place
items.summary: Itโs getting harder to beat the heat. During the summer of 2025, heat waves knocked out power grids in North America, Europe, and the Middle East. Global warming means more people need air-ยญconditioning, which requires more power and strains grids. But a millennia-old idea (plus 21st-century tech) โฆ
items.body: Itโs getting harder to beat the heat. During the summer of 2025, heat waves knocked out power grids in North America , Europe , and the Middle East . Global warming means more people need air-ยญconditioning, which requires more power and strains grids. But a millennia-old idea (plus 21st-century tech) might offer an answer: radiative cooling. Paints, coatings, and textiles can scatter sunlight and dissipate heatโno additional energy required. โRadiative cooling is universalโit exists everywhere in our daily life,โ says Qiaoqiang Gan, a professor of materials science and applied physics at King Abdullah University of Science and Technology in Saudi Arabia. Pretty much any object will absorb heat from the sun during the day and radiate some of it back at night. Itโs why cars parked outside overnight are often covered with condensation, Gan saysโtheir metal roofs dissipate heat into the sky, cooling the surfaces below the ambient air temperature. Thatโs how you get dew. Humans have harnessed this basic natural process for thousands of years. Desert peoples in Iran, North Africa, and India manufactured ice by leaving pools of water exposed to clear desert skies overnight, when radiativโฆ

items.body: Nature, Published online: 17 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09875-2 A detailed spatiotemporal roadmap of the human female and male reproductive tracts during key periods of sexual differentiation provides new cellular and molecular insights into how early axial gradients lead to specific cell lineages and tissue structures.

items.body: Nature, Published online: 17 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09842-x A three-dimensional (3D) nanofabrication platform based on metalens-generated focal spot arrays is introduced to parallelize two-photon lithography beyond centimetre-scale write field areas, revealing the potential of 3D nanolithography towards wafer-scale production.

items.title: The hidden cost of video-call glitches
items.summary:
Nature, Published online: 17 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03820-z

Video-call glitches might seem harmless, but they can reduce peopleโs chances of getting hired, closing a business deal or following a doctorโs recommendโฆ
items.body: Nature, Published online: 17 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03820-z Video-call glitches might seem harmless, but they can reduce peopleโs chances of getting hired, closing a business deal or following a doctorโs recommendation. Human brains expect video calls to feel like in-person conversations. When glitches break that illusion, it feels unsettling and strange, harming judgements of trustworthiness, likeability and credibility.

items.title: Mechanism for water formation on rocky exoplanets demonstrated in the lab
items.summary:
Nature, Published online: 17 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-04015-2

Experiments have revealed that the interaction between a hydrogen-rich atmosphere and a molten planet leads to high levels of water production. Through tโฆ
items.body: Nature, Published online: 17 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-04015-2 Experiments have revealed that the interaction between a hydrogen-rich atmosphere and a molten planet leads to high levels of water production. Through this process, planets could be enriched with water during their formation, altering their chemistry, evolution and, possibly, habitability.
